Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Investigating the Efficacy of Coordination of Damage Assessment Initiatives following the April 2015 Nepal Earthquake

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The April 2015 Nepal earthquake has resulted in a large number of local, national and international damage data collection efforts. Many organizations involved have a long history of responding to natural disasters and do so with a mandate from the national government or other recognized organization. There are other efforts that have emerged for the Nepal event that are not as coordinated, resulting in confusion to a variety of end-users as to the veracity, technical rigor, or openness of the data. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project aims to take a view on the damage datasets generated since the earthquake and assess the impact of each dataset in terms of the objectives and eventual end-use. This information will feed the development of data quality benchmarking criteria that can be used by any data collection effort following disaster events. The eventual impact is to reduce the uncertainty in future datasets and support the end-user to better understand the purpose, pedigree and appropriateness of the data for their specific use case.

The project will collect data from a number of sources and bring together a database of damage data for Nepal. In-country interviews with data suppliers and end-users will help the understanding of the impact of each dataset. Finally, criteria of best-practice will be generated to help inform users understand and compare data in future events. With evermore increasing technical capabilities for data collection, advancement of data processing, storage and online sharing, it is clear that the demand for open standards and interoperability is increasing. Therefore, it is crucial that data quality measures are clear and accessible to help openly compare data and reduce uncertainty to avoid unintended misuse of damage datasets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research explored the role and activities of data providers, developers, intermediaries, and end-users in the aftermath of the April 2015 Nepal earthquake. We conducted interviews and surveys of 51 individuals representing a wide variety of organizations who shared their experiences and suggestions for improved coordination of damage datasets for future disasters. While we were particularly interested in remote sensing imagery, we gathered information on all types of data used to make decisions about critical issues such as search and rescue operations, deployment of emergency response personnel, provision of supplies, and damage to the built environment and physical infrastructure.

We learned that that pre-existing, trusting relationships are key to swift action in the aftermath of disaster, both formal (e.g., via MOUs) and informal (e.g., individuals familiar with each other at various agencies and organizations). It was through these pre-existing relationships that action was possible. Where these relationships didn’t exist, data that was offered was seen as less credible and therefore not useful. Source credibility matters. Providers need to know what kind of data will be considered most trustworthy and useful by those in decision making roles (e.g., NGOs, government agencies). Data providers need to involve government agencies right away and help to make data available through government-supported means (e.g., website). Credible data intermediaries may be key. Likewise, perceptions of data accuracy depend on who’s providing it. Perceptions of data accuracy and credibility depend heavily on whether the providers are viewed as long-term allies and therefore trustworthy. Less sophisticated data generated by trusted providers is more likely to be used than more sophisticated data generated by providers who are unknown to the decision makers. Data must also be seen as value-added, above and beyond other sources of data (e.g., on-the-ground police reports of damage). In Nepal, and perhaps in all countries, the government must be involved directly in data collection, data management, and ownership – or potential end-users will hesitate to use the data. Data that hasn’t been either produced by the government or “approved” by the government may not be seen as credible and therefore not used to facilitate decision making, no matter its characteristics or otherwise objectively-determined utility.

We also learned that data management in the aftermath of a disaster can be challenging for end-users. For many end-users in Nepal, they were confronted with too much data, or data that was too fine-grained, or data that was produced without a clear sense of user needs, or data that was produced in forms and formats unusable by end users (for lack of technical capacity – both machines and human). End-users need individuals who can effectively serve as liaisons (bridges) between developers/providers and end-users. In the immediate aftermath of disaster, simple data is best. No one has the time or resources to work through complicated data sets. Later, as the recovery begins, more comprehensive data sets are needed to enable planning and decision making. In the beginning, at least, the simpler the communication, the more likely it is to be used. Ideally, data is translated from imagery to straightforward indicators with clear benefits communicated. Data needs to be in formats accessible to those with varying data reading skills levels (i.e., novice to expert) accompanied by different levels of explanation appropriate to various audiences. For example, government officials want/need data in simple formats, with clear, jargon-free explanations. In the wake of a disaster, end-users may not have reliable power due to outages, regular Internet access, or sufficient bandwidth. Technical capacity may be limited. The people who can facilitate interpretation of data will be in high demand in the immediate aftermath of a disaster. Decision makers need to use their time as efficiently as possible and recognize that there may not be many people available with the appropriate technical knowledge. This, capacity may be limited (1) in numbers of available people, and (2) in the knowledge and skills of those who are available.

Finally, we learned that data that allows “ballpark” decision making is good enough. In a world where rough estimates vs. more perfect estimates might be compared and contrasted, rough estimates will be seen as having as much if not more utility than more refined estimates. More time, more precision = higher cost. Higher cost without higher obvious benefit means that those data won’t be used. Fundamentally, expensive data will go unused. Governments in developing nations and NGOs need data that is free or practically free. They prefer simple data at low or no cost to more complex data at higher cost. Why? First, they do not have the funds needed to purchase more expensive data. Second, they cannot demonstrate ROI sufficient to warrant greater expenditures. 

Overall, the study emphasizes that collaboration among all partners, from providers to end-users, is essential to successful data utilization in the aftermath of disasters.
